div.p: PROUD AND TENDING to SHOW DESPISE:contempt IN-RELATION-TO OTHERS.

1. The most current general word for arrogance of attitude and in behaviour is probably jiāo 驕 (ant.* bēi 卑 "humble in attitude") which refers to an overbearing exaggerated self-confidence and does not essentially involve a negative attitude towards others.

2. Ào 傲 (ant. qiān 謙 "unassuming") is primarily an arrogant attitude towards others and a failure to recognise the dignity of others in action. (NB: Only in post-Buddhist times does the word come to designate justified pride.)
3. Jù 倨 (ant. gōng 恭 "show proper politeness") is primarily an informal physical pose and then by extension nonchalance and a failure to show proper respect for others.
4. Màn 慢 (ant. jìng 敬 "show proper respect") refers to arrogance in action as a failure to show proper diligence in polite behaviour towards someone.

5. Jiàn 僭 may perhaps be construed as arrogance as a result of a failure to recognise boundaries and limits to what is permissible for one, and where another person's responsibilities begin. But the word is marginal in the group. See ARROGATE.
翹尾巴 (coll) refers to snobbish self-importance.
老氣橫秋 refers to arrogant presumption of high status.
first rough draft to identify synonym group members for future analysis, based on CL. 18.11.2003. CH/

note.p: 504. C. Fronto: Superbia a superhabendo: arrogantia etiam in pauperem cadit.

504. Inter Superbiam et arrogantiam. Arrogantia est inanis gloria de eo quod quisque est. Superbia vero, supergrediens elatio mentis de eo quod non est. Superbiae autem gemina est differentia: Una quae spirituales ac summos viros per virtutum jactantiam dejicit, altera quae carnales erga seniorum imperium inobedientes reddit. Dicta autem superbia, quia super vult quam quod est.

note.p: 1. WL claims that jia1o 驕 is psychological and a4o 傲 is a matter of actions. THE MANY COUNTEREXAMPLES TO THIS NEED TO BE EXAMINED.

entry.def: Jù 倨 (ant. gōng 恭 "show proper politeness") is primarily an informal physical pose and then by extension nonchalance and a failure to show proper respect for others. [BEHAVIOUR], [HABITUAL], [HIGH-DEGREE], [IMPERSONAL]

Jù 倨 (ant. gōng 恭 "show proper politeness") is primarily an informal physical pose and then by extension nonchalance and a failure to show proper respect for others. [BEHAVIOUR], [HABITUAL], [HIGH-DEGREE], [IMPERSONAL]

sense.def: be arrogantly nonchalant in behaviour, be impolitely informal

entry.def: Ào 傲 (ant. qiān 謙 "unassuming") is primarily an arrogant attitude towards others and a failure to recognise the dignity of others in action. (NB: Only in post-Buddhist times does the word come to designate justified pride.) [DISPOSITION], [GRADED], [IMPERSONAL]

Ào 傲 (ant. qiān 謙 "unassuming") is primarily an arrogant attitude towards others and a failure to recognise the dignity of others in action. (NB: Only in post-Buddhist times does the word come to designate justified pride.) [DISPOSITION], [GRADED], [IMPERSONAL]

sense.def: make a show of arrogance; be arrogant to others in attitude and action
treat with arrogant disrespect; be arrogant towards be non-chalant vis-a-vis (e.g. punishments)
be proud (as one should be or naturally might be of great achievements)

entry.def: Jiàn 僭 may perhaps be construed as arrogance as a result of a failure to recognise boundaries and limits to what is permissible for one, and where another person's responsibilities begin. But the word is marginal in the group. [BEHAVIOUR], [OCCASIONAL], [PERSONAL]

sense.def: treat without proper restraint and respect for the rules of propriety ZUO 僭嫚於鬼神

entry.def: Màn 慢 (ant. jìng 敬 "show proper respect") refers to arrogance in action as a failure to show proper diligence in polite behaviour towards someone. [BEHAVIOUR], [HABITUAL!], [PERSONAL]

sense.def: show arrogant disrespect for someone, fail to pay proper polite attention to someone.
take an arrogant attutude towards Nab

entry.def: The most current general word for arrogance of attitude and in behaviour is probably jiāo 驕 (ant.* bēi 卑 "humble in attitude") which refers to an overbearing exaggerated self-confidence and does not essentially involve a negative attitude towards others. [DISPOSITION], [GENERAL], [IMPERSONAL]

sense.def: be arrogant because the contextually determinate N
arrogant and over-confident 驕君 "arrogant ruler"
be overconfident, overbearing; haughty, arrogant, self-important
be arrogant in behaviour, be overconfident
treat arrogantly 嚴於, fail to show proper respect
cause to be arrogant and over-confident

take pride in (oneself); be arrogant [the reflexive pronoun is hard to explain, for the meaning of this phrase is NOT "arrogant towards oneself". It is as if we have a medial VP. Not current in MSC or in TPGJ.]
consider as arrogant (or: declare to be arrogant?)
be arrogant towards> proudly look down upon
be impolite; fail to show proper politeness according to ritual
behave in a self-assertive arrogant manner
BUDDH: self-pride, egotism, arrogance; skr. abhimāna; ātma-mada

bibl.title: 正法華經 Zhèng fǎhuá jīng Saddharmapunnarnkasūtra, Lotus sutra Taishō

sense.def: be arrogant so as to become remiss
cause to become arrogant and self-glorifying

bibl.title: 佛光大辭典 Fóguāng dàcídiǎn The Foguang Dictionary of Buddhism

sense.def: BUDDH: arrogance and self-pride (devaluating the achievements of others and exaggerating one's own achievements; compare gònggāo zìdà 貢高自大 in LOTUS(B): 109á8); see also zēngshàng màn 增上慢)
callous lack of brotherly-care-like sympathy and concern
